en_first_half: “Sorry,” he said without looking up. It was a well-known fact that I was opposed to prom. Absolutely nothing about any of it appealed to me—not slow dancing, not fast dancing, not the dresses, and definitely
en_second_half: not the rented tuxedo. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me an excellent way to contract some hideous disease from its previous tenant, and I did not aspire to become the world’s only virgin with pubic lice.
en_Completion: not the awkward photos that would be taken in front of a cheesy backdrop, not the overpriced tickets, and not the inevitable drama that would ensue. en_first_half: Her lips were so close to me that I could feel her smile. “I’m afraid it’s not possible,” she whispered. She let go then, but kept looking at me, taking step after step backward. She raised her
en_second_half: eyebrows finally, and smiled, and I believed the smile. I watched her climb up a tree and then lift herself onto the roof outside of her second-floor bedroom window. She jimmied her window open and crawled inside.
en_Completion: hand, and I could see the glint of a small key in her palm. "I'm sorry," she said, her voice barely audible over the sound of the wind rustling through the trees. "I really am." She turned then, and disappeared into the darkness, leaving me standing alone in the moonlit garden.

es_first_half: Mi madre me habló una vez de un niño loco con el que trabajaba. Había sido un niño completamente normal hasta los nueve años, cuando murió su padre. Y aunque
es_second_half: es evidente que a un montón de niños de nueve años se les muere el padre, y la mayoría no se vuelven locos, supongo que aquel niño fue una excepción.
es_Completion: su madre se esforzó por cuidarlo y darle todo el amor que necesitaba, el niño comenzó a cambiar. Se volvió cada vez más introvertido y solitario, y su comportamiento se tornó cada vez más extraño. Mi madre me contó que el niño empezó a hablar solo y a reírse sin motivo, y que a veces se quedaba mirando fijamente a la pared durante horas

es_second_half: me subió dolorosamente por la garganta. Solo entonces, tras haber perdido tanto tiempo, entendí lo mal que había interpretado tanto el juego de Margo como el premio por ganarlo.

en_second_half: spent most of my life being afraid is that I have been trying to prepare myself, to train my body for the real fear when it comes. But I am not prepared.
en_Completion: been having so much trouble breathing is that I have been trying to breathe the atmosphere's own stale breath. The smell is like a punch to the gut, a wake-up call that I have been sleepwalking through life, oblivious to the suffocating grip of the world around me. en_second_half: old day-by-day calendar, the days scattered through the room, all of them yellowing and mouse-bit. I wonder if this might once have been a little bookstore, although it’s been decades since these shelves held anything but dust.

The light flickers, casting eerie shadows on the walls as we make our way deeper into the room.

en_first_half: Talking like this to her kept me calm, strangely. It kept me from imagining the possibilities. I came again to the sagging wooden sign for Grovepoint Acres. I could almost hear the sighs of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road. It looked like a driveway without a house. I left RHAPAW running and got out. From close up, I could see that Grovepoint Acres was more finished than it initially appeared. Two dirt roads
en_second_half: ending in cul-de-sacs had been cut into the dusty ground, although the roads had eroded so much I could barely see their outlines. As I walked up and down both streets, I could feel the heat in my nose with each breath. The scalding sun made it hard to move, but I knew the beautiful, if morbid, truth: heat made death reek, and Grovepoint Acres smelled like nothing except cooked air and car exhaust—our cumulative exhalations held close to the surface by the humidity.

es_first_half: Por raro que parezca, dirigirme a ella en voz alta me tranquilizaba. Evitaba que imaginara las diversas posibilidades. Llegué al letrero de madera roída de Grovepoint Acres. Casi oí los suspiros de alivio de los que me seguían cuando giré a la izquierda hacia la carretera asfaltada sin salida. Parecía un camino de acceso a una casa pero sin casa. Dejé el Chuco en marcha y salí. Al acercarme, vi que Grovepoint Acres estaba más acabado de lo que en un primer momento parecía. Habían
es_second_half: abierto en el suelo dos caminos de tierra sin salida, aunque se habían erosionado tanto que apenas se veían los contornos. Recorrí las dos calles arriba y abajo sintiendo el calor en la nariz cada vez que respiraba. El sol abrasador dificultaba el movimiento, pero sabía la bonita, aunque macabra, verdad: el calor hace que los muertos apesten, y Grovepoint Acres solo olía a aire caliente y tubos de escape. La humedad hacía que la acumulación de exhalaciones se mantuviera en el aire a mi alrededor.
es_Completion: dejado de construirlo hacía mucho tiempo, pero alguien había intentado mantenerlo en pie. La madera estaba podrida y las ventanas rotas, pero la estructura seguía en pie. en_first_half: Unlike the previous pseudovisions, someone was keeping up Quail Hollow. No houses had been built, but the lots were marked with surveying stakes, and the grass was freshly mown. All the streets were paved and named with road signs. In the subdivision’s center, a perfectly circular lake had been dug and then, for some reason, drained. As I drove up in the minivan, I could see it was about
en_second_half: ten feet deep and several hundred feet in diameter. A hose snaked across the bottom of the crater to the middle, where a steel-and-aluminum fountain rose from the bottom to eye level. I found myself feeling thankful the lake was empty, so I wouldn’t have to stare into the water and wonder if she was in the bottom somewhere, expecting me to put on scuba gear to find her.

en_second_half: I didn’t know if it was older than the other pseudovisions, or if the low-lying, swamp-wet land made everything grow faster, but the Collier Farms access road became impassable just after I turned in because a thick grove of brambly brush had sprouted across the entire road.

st_first_half: "Ke rata li-strings. Kamehla ke na le. Hobane ke kamoo e ikutloang kateng. Empa li-strings li etsa hore bohloko bo bonahale bo bolaea ho feta kamoo e leng kateng, ke nahana. Ha rea lokela ho ba joalo ka ha li-strings li etsa hore re lumele. I like the ho, too. Joang bo
st_second_half: ile ba nkhothaletsa ho u thusa ho nahana u le motho oa sebele. Empa ha re fapane le semela se le seng. Ha ke khone ho ba uena. U ke ke ua ba uena. U ka nahana ka e 'ngoe ea li-tab tse ntle, empa ha ho letho le phethahetseng, na ua tseba?
